p: Overall, the EO yield of the dried leaves of J. excelsa (1.16%) was lower than that of J. sabina (1.98%) ( Table 2). However, the EO yield of both junipers varied among different accessions, from 0.60% to 1.87% in J. excelsa and from 1.38% to 2.73% in J. sabina, suggesting significant variability occurring within a population ( Table 2). These results demonstrated that high- yielding EO accessions of the two junipers could be identified and selected from the natural populations for the potential commercial production of EO.
